name: NPR
text: President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President Pence, are making preparations to get the coronavirus vaccine, hoping to instill trust and confidence in the vaccine ahead of its widespread distribution as the death toll climbs to new heights. https://t.co/lutdvLb0Ev

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President Mike Pence are making preparations to get the COVID-19 vaccine — hoping to instill trust and confidence in it ahead of its widespread distribution.
https://t.co/YiHGJYr1Zw

name: NPR
text:
About 80 million people didn't vote in the 2020 election. What motivated them?

A new survey finds nonvoters say they're disengaged and disaffected. They're also more likely to be Latino, younger, make less money and have lower levels of education.
https://t.co/ZFG47Nj4Ej

name: NPR
text:
RT @SachaPfeiffer: They're called "forever prisoners" -- held at Guantánamo without charge or trial.
 
There are more than two dozen of them at Gitmo.
 
And, in a rare development, one has been cleared for release after 18 years behind bars. https://t.co/VkgwF0i49R

name: NPR
text:
Russian government hackers are believed to be responsible for infiltrating computer systems at multiple U.S. agencies in recent months — including the Pentagon, DHS and the U.S. Treasury, government agencies report.

Here's what key players are saying.
https://t.co/YzD9biFXyQ

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Joe Biden is looking to Franklin Delano Roosevelt's transition to the presidency for inspiration as he and his team prepare to tackle a nation in the middle of numerous crises.
https://t.co/wOOGDgNiOO

name: NPR
text:
Many people who work as Santa or Mrs. Klaus depend on that income to pay for necessities like food and rent — and many are at increased risk for COVID-19 because of their age or weight.

Now, they're having to make tough choices about how to adjust.
https://t.co/EEoQyDzgRu

name: NPR
text:
The city of Paris has been fined for appointing too many women to senior positions in the government — violating a rule that at least 40% of such positions go to people of each gender.
https://t.co/SoprEDHnHx

name: NPR
text:
An ex-Houston police captain was arrested after allegedly running a man off the road and restraining him with a pistol in an attempt to prove a nonexistent voter fraud scheme in exchange for more than $250,000, prosecutors said. @HoustonPubMedia
https://t.co/Rs67G5cXGc

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking President-elect Joe Biden's cabinet nominees and advisers. Here's a look at how the administration is shaping up so far.
https://t.co/Bm6Sx8mSNm

name: NPR
text:
Maryland's Republican Gov. Larry Hogan has been named the new co-chair of No Labels, a bipartisan group that will push centrist political ideas as new Congress is set to convene early next year.
https://t.co/q6kOizkPy4

name: NPR
text:
"Time is the most cinematic of subjects," says director Christopher Nolan, whose films often explore the concept. "Before the movie camera came along, human beings had no way of seeing time backwards, slowed down, sped up." 
https://t.co/DiAV6hgrs3

name: NPR
text:
It's been 50 years since Puerto Rican singer José Feliciano came up with the seasonal earworm "Feliz Navidad."

Now, he's celebrating the anniversary with a new recording, a new children's book and a livestreamed concert on Dec. 20.
https://t.co/6iPFBImQnp

name: NPR
text:
Watch members of the celebrated Borromeo String Quartet tap into the sillier side of Beethoven — who was born 250 years ago this week — using music the composer wrote late in life.
https://t.co/nJfubGkaXq

name: NPR
text:
Shane Reilly's yard is carpeted in small flags — more than 24,000 of them. For 8 months, the Austin resident has planted one for each Texan who has died of COVID-19.

“I ran out of room a while ago,” he tells @KUT. https://t.co/dLuQm1pHi9

name: NPR
text: Linda Warren says that when her family found out she was gay, they disowned her. So for the past 22 years, she's dressed up as "Queer Santa" and made sure that other kids rejected by their families still get presents. @CPRNews https://t.co/D0c5NdI0XB

name: NPR
text: The 120 foundations NPR identified are linked to some of the nation's richest people: an oil magnate, a cable television tycoon, the families of Walt Disney and Warren Buffett. All took federal funds to cover shortfalls instead of tapping their own wealth. https://t.co/zkh2YG2sMh

name: NPR
text:
Amid the pandemic, a third of U.S. families -- even some making more than $200,000 -- say they're having difficulty covering everyday costs. 

As wages fall further behind soaring home, college and health care costs, more are living paycheck to paycheck. https://t.co/inWxbasLY9

name: NPR
text: Just In: Despite record-setting Black Friday and Cyber Monday business, retail sales declined 1.1% in November as t… https://t.co/mA2FOnTOAp

name: NPR
text: Still, the National Retail Federation is forecasting that retail sales will grow between 3.6% and 5.2% to their highest level ever during the holiday season, with the average shopper spending $998 on gifts, food, decorations and other holiday items. https://t.co/8YY2STJ1Ps

name: NPR
text: Breaking: The U.S. Supreme Court says it will take up an appeal from the NCAA defending rules that restrict paying… https://t.co/WinpkB1BWn

name: NPR
text:
RT @LouderThanARiot: A prison so neglected, it’s lethal.
A hip-hop alliance with the power to demand justice.
Two generations of prison abolitionists.

On the finale of #LouderThanARiot: Can hip-hop make the revolution irresistible? Midnight ET.

Subscribe & catch up now: https://t.co/JoTA7c0mN6

name: NPR
text: Congressional aides say legislators are closing in a new $900 billion coronavirus relief package. It's expected to include stimulus checks, further unemployment insurance, an extended ban on evictions and a continued pause on student loan payments. https://t.co/lILJm8nme0

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRCodeSwitch: 🚨NEW EPISODE ALERT 🚨

Guns. They're as American as 🥧. They represent independence & self reliance. But...not so much if you're Black. 

On this episode, we're getting into the complicated history (and present) of Black gun ownership with @teamtrace. 
https://t.co/pxanLZOa5c

name: NPR
text:
Polarization and mass disinformation have increased threats of political violence, all the way down to municipal health officials. 

"The most controversial thing that we were dealing with, really, up until March were septic system approvals." https://t.co/K2ec5vxMlN

name: NPR
text:
RT @alinaselyukh: In the pandemic, a THIRD of Americans struggle to cover usual bills, like food or car payments -- even earners above $100,000. 
But teetering on a financial edge is nothing new for many families -- actually, MOST families -- in this country. 
https://t.co/eCQtF6HZdb

name: NPR
text: RT @alinaselyukh: What gives? I posed this question to experts. Searched for answers in data. And then, discussed it at great length with three families that dug deep into their past -- and their bank statements. https://t.co/Tvc8o2rg7A
